For commit messages please follow https://cbea.ms/git-commit/
    Separate subject from body with a blank line
    Limit the subject line to 50 characters
    Capitalize the subject line
    Do not end the subject line with a period
    Use the imperative mood in the subject line
    Wrap the body at 72 characters
    Use the body to explain what and why vs. how
Is this all implemented in bmcweb?

Yes, implemented: https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/scripts/update_schemas.py
Redifish schema v1 included in `include_list`
I would recommend the name of table to be added in the quick links section like other tables in the page.
What about the bmcweb support here?
Don't we need to arrange these in alphabetical order?

Why do we want to assume 0 here?
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/5e7e2dc585dc7a7e62d2b648b541e7f50c39ea5d/redfish-core/lib/pcie.hpp#L355
We think that the most important thing is fact of existence of the PCIe card, not its insides.

Can we make some dropdown for functions under each device dropdown?

For example NVIDIA PCIe videocard is represented as two functions:
```
21:00.0 VGA compatible controller: NVIDIA Corporation GM107GL [Quadro K620] (rev a2)
21:00.1 Audio device: NVIDIA Corporation GM107 High Definition Audio Controller [GeForce 940MX] (rev a1)
```
As you can see these functions have different information (take for example `DeviceClass`):
```
.DeviceType                        "MultiFunction"
.Function0ClassCode                "0x030000"
.Function0DeviceClass              "DisplayController"
.Function0DeviceId                 "0x13bb"
.Function0FunctionType             "Physical"
.Function0RevisionId               "0xa2"
.Function0SubsystemId              "0x1098"
.Function0SubsystemVendorId        "0x10de"

.Function0VendorId                 "0x10de"
.Function1ClassCode                "0x040300"
.Function1DeviceClass              "MultimediaController"
.Function1DeviceId                 "0x0fbc"
.Function1FunctionType             "Physical"
.Function1RevisionId               "0xa1"
.Function1SubsystemId              "0x1098"
.Function1SubsystemVendorId        "0x10de"
.Function1VendorId                 "0x10de"
```
So we need to be able to display both functions as separate dropdown instances under their device.
And you just print all the properties from the `Function0` as overall device properties.

Overall the interface is described here:

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/PCIeDevice.interface.yaml

So for the device the mapping of D-Bus fields to Redfish looks like this:
```
DeviceType          -> PCIeDevice.DeviceType
GenerationInUse     -> PCIeDevice.PCIeInterface.PCIeType
GenerationSupported -> PCIeDevice.PCIeInterface.MaxPCIeType
Manufacturer        -> PCIeDevice.Manufacturer
MaxLanes            -> PCIeDevice.PCIeInterface.MaxLanes
LanesInUse          -> PCIeDevice.PCIeInterface.LanesInUse
```

And for each available function:
```
ClassCode           -> PCIeFunctions.ClassCode
DeviceClass         -> PCIeFunctions.DeviceClass
DeviceId            -> PCIeFunctions.DeviceId
FunctionType        -> PCIeFunctions.FunctionType
RevisionId          -> PCIeFunctions.RevisionId
SubsystemId         -> PCIeFunctions.SubsystemId
SubsystemVendorId   -> PCIeFunctions.SubsystemVendorId
VendorId            -> PCIeFunctions.VendorId
```

It looks like `hardware-status/inventory` page loading now never ends.
Could you check that?

Yes, you are right.
Blue loading bar never ends.

Hello! I'm currently working on an application that would pass PCIe devices information from host to BMC via IPMI BLOB protocol, similar to `smbios-mdr` application.
I've tested this patchset on my system and here are some comments:
